dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cashier hands a boy, 13, his change across a counter. T boy stuffs the coins in his pocket. He lifts the cardboar tray with two hot dogs, a bag of chips, and two Cokes. Th is Claude. We follow him: He carefully carries the meal down the ais balances it in one hand as he opens the door. The train noise blares as he traverses the area between c He enters the new car repeating the balancing act. He wai while a man shoves his back-pack onto the metal rack abov the seats. Claude hurries a bit more now, his concentrati alternating between the food and the path. He sits next to a brunette woman.   He hands her a hot do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. He's met by a severe and pinched face. The eyes have blac circles -- there is a scar above her lip. Claude instantl blushes and mumbles:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. He gets up and hurries a few seats further. He slides nex to a pretty brunette woman, late 30's, with straight shou length hair. Her name is Margot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sat next to the wrong person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?   Where? She stretches up and peers over the seats.   He grabs her shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't look.    She'll see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful with my blouse.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Margot is sleeping, her head against the window. Claude listens to his iPod. He takes out the earphones, gets up, and walks to the front of the car. Opens the door and goe between cars. The train roars and screeches. Claude screams.   He stops looks around. He screams again.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Claude and his mother gaze out the dirt streaked window a river. An old castle-like structure emerges from the wate Houses are run-down. In the distance there's a power plan Electrical lines crisscross the sky. Claude puts his fing against the glass and traces the wires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will the wedding be crowded?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I think she doesn't know anyone anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long has she known Malcolm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that short?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you marry someone you'd only known a year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to ever get married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't say I have a lot of hope for the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are we going then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're supporting her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought she wasn't speaking to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...no...I wasn't speaking to her, but I'm over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ferry is docked. Cars pull up onto the boat. Margot run clutching a suitcase, holding down a floppy wine colored hat. Claude hurries alongside her, a bag slung over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rumbling and sputtering of the boat.    People get ou their cars and stretch their legs. Claude leans against the rail and lets the spray hit his face. Margot's cell vibrates. The caller ID: HOME. She stuffs the phone in her pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why aren't you wearing your new shades?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I need them right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You begged for those glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but...I will wear them, I just feel like people might think it's weird that a kid is wearing dark shades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's ridiculous. Claude reluctantly takes out a pair of thin wrap-around p sunglasses and puts them on. He looks around self- consciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look very cool. He takes them off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need them right now.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Margot and Claude wait.   The ferry has emptied out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do they know we're here? A maroon Volvo station wagon peels around a bend and stop across the road. Two eyes peer out from just below the backseat window. A man, 40, in dumpy cargo shorts rolls d the window. He has a small moustache -- he's harried and sweaty. This is Malcolm. He points at Margot and Claude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm drives. He smokes with the window open. Margot is in the passenger seat. In the back, Claude and the girl, Ingrid, sit shyly, their hair blows turbulently in the wi Ingrid, 11, wears shorts, sandals, and a batik shirt with panda on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul apologizes for not coming, she's still getting the house ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry it was such short notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care. Paul's frantic, but I don't give a shit. Oh, and Ingrid wants me to tell you that she made us all bracelets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I wanted...I wanted to wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I thought you asked me to tell them. Anyway... Malcolm holds up his wrist and shows a knit blue and oran bracelet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got Knicks colors. INGRID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not Knicks colors! MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful, Ingrid. INGRID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Claude) I made this one for myself. She shows him the purple and green one around her wrist. INGRID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yours is yellow. Is that okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess. INGRID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your dad and Josh? CLAUDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They might come later. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh's spring break is next week. Jim teaches through Friday and then they open the house in Vermont on the weekend. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bluntly) It means a lot to Pauline that you're here. Margot nods awkwardly -- she blushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.     Good. A car suddenly pulls out of a driveway, but nowhere near their car. Malcolm swerves anyway. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy Jesus! Watch it, dicksack! Ingrid giggles.    Margot clutches the handle above the d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're wondering about the moustache --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a full beard   for a while and then when I shaved   it I left this part for last, you   know to see how it looked, and...    It's meant to be funny. Margot nods politely.   The sound of tires on gravel:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trunk slams shut. The Volvo is parked in a driveway alongside a grey Colonial house that sits above the water They lift bags. An old mutt ambles toward them. Pauline emerges from the house. She's pretty like her sister, late 30's. She walks briskly toward them. Margot smiles and opens her arms, but Pauline passes her and dip down to embrace Claude. She kisses him on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so handsome. Now she hugs Margot.    They both tear up.   Claude beams

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never thought I'd get you here. A loud thud. They all turn toward the property fence. A large pile of dead flowers and rotting plants has been du into their yard. There's whispering and movement through brush on the other side. Margot looks at Pauline with concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're arriving in the midst of a drama. Ingrid, make sure Wizard is inside. Malcolm trudges over to the trash cans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Voglers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The neighbors want us to cut down our tree. She indicates a large oak that extends up and into the adjoining property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's our tree!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They think it's sick and rotting their property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're having the ceremony under it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You took the swing down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pauline thinks this is their way of trying to be friends. I think they resent us because we're... He searches for the word, but can't come up with anything He says wearily:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude sits on the squeaky bed, a yellow bracelet on his wrist. An old flip-clock hums on the night-table. A door opens onto a bathroom which has another door open onto another bedroom. Ingrid sits on her bed observing Claude. She holds a realistic-looking stuffed rooster in an old-style tuxedo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like showers or baths?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showers.   What about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ingrid shrugs.   She says, already bored with the topic:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pauline and Margot carry bags up the stairs. Margot now wears a knit red bracelet. They're tentative with one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Malcolm what you thought he'd be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I didn't know what to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moustache is temporary. He left it for last when he was shaving. It's meant to be funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... They enter the guest room. The windows are wide open, the curtains blowing, but the room is very neatly made up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry -- with so little time to prepare, we had to put you in Malcolm's storage room --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was Becky's room.   Poor Becky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, poor Becky. Now it's a storage room. I've just started to feel like it's our house not my parents. You know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. It might still smell like paint, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought he was a musician. Pauline jimmies down the stiff windows. Margot begins to unpack and hang up clothes in the closet. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, music's officially a hobby... He's painting now. And writing letters to newspapers and magazines. He's very meticulous, he'll spend up to a week writing a response to a music review. He's incredibly smart. Maybe too smart. I don't know. We're doing very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.    I mean, you must be. Silence. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know where to begin. What can I tell you? It seems I'm pregnant, but it's really early so... I haven't told anyone. I mean, I haven't told Malcolm or Ingrid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow... PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, if it sticks. We'll see. I hope so. Things are good. We did a couples seminar two months ago or so in Maine. They give you exercises and things to do. I know you're not convinced, but... MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vaguely) Mm hm. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got engaged right afterwards. The guy who runs it, Strickland, wrote a really interesting book about loving which I'll lend you if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (non-committal) Okay. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But only if you'll read it. Because I need it back. I made notes in the margins. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I may not get to it for a while. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not going to lend it to you if you're not going to read it. They meet eyes.   Pauline quickly turns away. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be very informal by the way. Just Mom and Becky. Malcolm's brother. Few friends. And now you and Claude. Nothing like the first one. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wary) Becky's coming? PAULINE/MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She isn't how you.../I'd really like... PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to say, "I'd really like some white wine." PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah. We have a... Well...I'm glad you changed your mind and came. I never heard from you after I sent the invite...I even wondered if you got it. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Well, I'm so pleased we're here. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Pauline waits for an explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry you were so angry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't angry. I was...disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh. But you see when you say, "disappointed" it puts me in a crummy situation. Like I let you down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you did in a way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see it like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. I felt betrayed.    Is that word okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, you're making me the aggressor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were the aggressor. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not... I've become a really good cook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm strums his guitar and smokes. Pauline sits at his feet with Ingrid and Claude. The kids look at a record sleeve. Margot is curled up on the sofa writing in a litt brown notebook. She wears oval tortoise-shell glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you've still got all of our old records. Ingrid pulls an album toward her. Her eyes widen at the scary image on the cover. She quickly turns it over and hands it to her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INGRID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, can you hide this please. Pauline puts the record sleeve on top of a shelf. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (for Margot's benefit) Malcolm played with Ric Ocasek once? MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the late `80's. It was a solo gig after he left the Cars. CLAUDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you're kind of famous. Malcolm reddens. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No. Believe me, I'm not. I used to want to be, but, No. Do you want to be famous? MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude wants to be very famous. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, make sure you can handle rejection. I can't. For me, expectation just turns to disappointment. So, ultimately I'd rather not try. It'll all go black for us soon enough anyway. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude, ignore him. Pauline sneaks a look at Margot who is watching Malcolm w an expression of either contempt or confusion. Pauline gr uncomfortable. She says to Claude: PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When your mother moved to New York she used to send me books and records. She sent me REM's Murmur... MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the Pixies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And X. She was very cool your mother. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You only liked top forty. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I love REM now. Margot takes off her reading glasses and rubs her eyes. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't really listen to music anymore. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was dating that guy, Horace back then. Remember him? MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that the guy who liked to rough you up? PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that was our dad. Pauline and Margot crack up laughing.   Malcolm raises an eyebrow at Claude. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our father used to strip down to his skivvies and beat us with a belt. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man had a sexual screw loose. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's awful -- that stuff that happens to kids. Malcolm was fondled by a male baby-sitter. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just use that information however you want... PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. We're with family.     I figured... Claude looks at Malcolm.   Malcolm doesn't meet his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Becky got it the worst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she ever. Raped by the horse trainer... Margot breaks into laughter. Pauline spits her seltzer ba into the glass. They both laugh hysterically. Tears strea down Margot's face. Claude watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm, Pauline, Margot, Claude and Ingrid sit with a homosexual couple, Alan, 40's, and Toby, 30's, and their Bruce, 8, at an old wooden table eating crab, salad and s Part of Alan's face is paralyzed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan rolled over in bed and looked at me and he said I can't feel my face. It took three doctors before we knew it was Bells Palsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say a brush of wind can do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feeling is slowly coming back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all getting older... Which is terrible -- I don't care how universal it is. I can't remember names anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have that. I blank out on certain words now too. Like the other day, I couldn't remember the word for... (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've forgotten it again. The stuff in wine. Sediment! That was it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that. I was talking more about not remembering who was the bassist for Motley CrГјe. Malcolm lights up a cigarette.   He offers one to Claude shakes his head, No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ingrid, why don't you show Claude and Bruce the game trunk. INGRID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Claude reluctantly follows Ingrid and Bruce.      He look longingly at the table of adults. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved, to himself) Mick Mars. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby, I think you need to have Bruce diagnosed. TOBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margot, I don't want to have this conversation with you. We follow the kids inside.   We hear in the background: MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's vital. If you keep telling him he's like everyone else he'll wonder why he isn't. He's suffering. TOBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's tested very well.    He does B's in school. Claude stops -- his mother and Toby are arguing out the window. Her eyes meet his for a second -- they make no connection -- she goes back to Toby. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, that's how autism works. One part of the brain can work fine while the other is damaged. ALAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had him diagnosed, Margot. Nothing was found wrong. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you really, though? TOBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm...I'm not going to have this conversation. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it must be so difficult for you, but I think you have to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pauline unloads the plates onto the kitchen counter.   Sh hesitates and exhales a deep, anxious breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margot paces while talking on a cell phone in the herb garden. She drinks a white wine with ice cubes and smokes joint. The bottle lies at her feet, three-quarters empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I left you a note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come back. Or meet me in Vermont on Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...no. The wedding is on Saturday. I'm here for that. I can't really pull out. How would that look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't spoken to her in years -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we're speaking now. She is my closest friend despite it all... You're the one who's been trying to get me to call her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you tell Claude what you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, this guy, Malcolm. He's exactly what you'd imagine except I think he's clinically depressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not ugly, but completely unattractive. And he has no job. The best I can make out is that he's a letter writer. I don't know, the house looks weird to me...she's trying too hard and it's kind of a mess...they took down the swing... Silence on the other end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you weren't a hundred percent on this. You said that like a week ago. Can I come up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I don't want to see you -- I feel happier already having done it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? You feel happier... (silence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't tell Claude anything please, until we've talked more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to tell him. And we need to tell Josh. Did he do his homework?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is happening and you have to get your mind around that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude sleeps in bed.    Margot gently touches his face. whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you asleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you remember this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just talked to your dad... Claude's eyes remained closed, but he smiles. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only going to tell you if you won't remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Margot hesitates.    She changes her mind and says thoughtfully: MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone finds you so funny and charming. I always get compliments about you. Margot stands. She catches herself in a warped mirror and smears some eye make-up off of her face. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you having fun?    Is it nice to see Pauline? CLAUDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opens his eyes) Yeah, I really like her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.     She is crazy though. CLAUDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In what way? MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's really berserk. Maybe it's hormones. You don't notice anything different about Pauline?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's pregnant -- she told me. But she's keeping it a secret -- I mean from Malcolm and even Ingrid. Which I think is unforgiveable. Now she'll have to marry him. What's she planning -- to get married and not drink champagne? Then she'll just be lying. I guess she's afraid she'll miscarry. She probably will. I think on some level she's ambivalent about the marriage and that's why she's not telling him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you stoned, Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water runs from the bathroom. Malcolm cradles a glass of whiskey and stands nude in front of a full length mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My scrotum is longer than my penis. He turns around and looks at his ass. Pauline walks out o the bathroom. She wears mens pajamas, the top open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's sweet how Claude looks up to me. He waits for a reaction and gets none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margot doesn't seem as crazy as you made her out to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What she did to Toby and Alan tonight didn't seem crazy enough for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess that seemed pretty crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (immediately defensive) Well, she cares deeply. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, she's really worried about Bruce. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has nothing to do with Bruce. She thinks everyone is autistic. Malcolm is about to speak, but instead he halts, paralyze PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, you keep changing your position -- I'm just trying to figure out if I should agree with you or not? PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, can't she be both, care deeply and be crazy? Do people have to be all one thing? MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

She wanders arou to the back of the house. She looks into a lighted window It's a white tiled bathroom. A wet brown animal body covered in clear plastic is balan on the sink. Mr. Vogler tears into the plastic. The carca is butterflied open exposing the innards and ribs. Mrs. Vogler runs the tub. She pours salt from a box in th water. The blade pierces the bone with a violent release and the hoof falls to the floor. Margot moves to another window.   The pig's face now look her. Blood drips and leaks into the crevices of the tile. The woman brandishes a syringe filled with an orange liquid. Suddenly a face appears in the glass. Margot leaps back. It's a thin boy. He says something. The family turns to t window. The father flicks off the bathroom light. From inside Margot illuminates like an apparition. Margot scampers into the trees.   She pushes through bran her shirt tears. She runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude sits on the bed. The record sleeve from Blondie's "Parallel Lines" rests in his lap. He reads the lyrics to the song, "Sunday Girl." He depresses the red record butt on an old portable tape recorder. He sings a cappella and full voice, passionately, as sweetly as he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maisy appears in the doorway and watches.   Claude turns lyric. He jumps, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Singing? Fumbling, Claude shuts off the tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm?     A bit. She drifts into the room and hovers closely above Claude remains on the bed. Margot passes by in the hallway, disheveled from her esca She watches: Maisy takes the lyric sleeve from Claude's hands. Her T-shirt hangs above her waist showing her smoo stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I make a suggestion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should get underarm deodorant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kind of smell. Claude blushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better I tell you than someone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margot puts on mascara and watches Claude, who stands beh her, in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you smell nice.    You smell real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stink.

dialogues.text: It causes cancer.

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: Underarm deodorant?

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: Yes. It's got chemicals and things that are extremely harmful.

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: I'm not going to die from underarm cancer.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: No, you'll get it somewhere else. Like your stomach or your testicles.

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: (laughs) Testicles.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: Don't laugh, that's a serious thing. Who told you this, anyway? Maisy?

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: I hope you're not interested in that girl. I find her insufferable.

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: It means I can't suffer her. She's loud and stupid. She goes on about things of which she knows nothing about.

dialogues.speaker: CLAUDE
dialogues.text: She got into Harvard early.

dialogues.speaker: MARGOT
dialogues.text: Stupid people get into Harvard early all the time.

dialogues.text: Where did you go again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnard. (pause)

dialogues.text: I just don't think you should do anything with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're just friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out with Paul and Malcolm and Dick.

Claude and Ingrid sit on the couch, hamburgers in front o them. Maisy is cross-legged on Wizard's dog bed and chews stalk of celery.

dialogues.text: Who do we know who's gay?

dialogues.text: He might be, it's very common. CLAUDE

dialogues.text: No she isn't.

dialogues.text: Do you think your mom is fuckable? CLAUDE

dialogues.text: Margot used to never speak. I remember when we went on a double date in high school, that kid Ron asked you if English was your first language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thought you were aphasic.

dialogues.text: I'm still not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, Margot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very possible, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just...your diagnoses sometimes irk the hell out of me. Malcolm lights another cigarette -- the car jerks sideway MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm, can you slow down. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can drive if you like. MALCOLM

dialogues.text: No, you got dinner, the driving's on me. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Well, neither Pauline or I ordered dessert. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm, let it go. (taunting) Margot would insist on driving if she knew how. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dick) My license elapsed.   But I know how. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's probably for the best. I have this theory, I think, historically, women have been held back in so many ways that when they get power, like they do behind the wheel, they can't help but abuse it. It's akin to Hannah Arendt's Eichmann theory about prison guards and prisoners switching rolls. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a charming philosophy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   Tell that one a lot. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a blanket thing. I mean, women can be great drivers too... He takes a long satisfied drag on his cigarette. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said the man with the moustache that he thinks he's wearing in quotes. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's meant to be funny. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Pauline, re: Margot) Are you doing this for her benefit or mine? Malcolm pumps the brake. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck? PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (momentarily sober) No, there they go. Okay. It's fine. I thought I had no brakes for a minute... Malcolm pitches his cigarette out the window -- it flies through Margot's window and lands on her lap. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm! Dick grabs the lit butt and chucks it in the road. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning around) What?! The car swerves again -- everyone jumps. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine, Margot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Malcolm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just so incompetent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you fucking drive yourselves home! Malcolm screeches the vehicle over to the shoulder.   The jolt to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God. Pauline opens the door and staggers toward the brush. She leans against a tree and looks like she might vomit. Malc watches in the rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should go after her. Malcolm sighs heavily and gets out of the car. Margot and Dick watch out the back window. Pauline sees Malcolm comi and bolts into the woods. Malcolm charges after her.

dialogues.text: Come back with me tonight.

dialogues.text: Come on, I've been trying to get you up here all year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vaguely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Claude lies in bed with Ingrid. He chews off a piece of h pinky fingernail. He hesitates and places it on an end- table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INGRID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you putting that there? CLAUDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to keep it. INGRID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I left a piece of skin in a movie theater once so it could watch movies all its life. CLAUDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if it's the same thing. INGRID

dialogues.text: No. INGRID

dialogues.text: I'm going to kiss your cheek and then you kiss mine. CLAUDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to do that. INGRID

dialogues.text: Why not? CLAUDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's pointless... Claude hears footsteps creak downstairs. He goes to the d and peers out: Pauline and Malcolm, a little disheveled a dirty, climb the stairs. Neither speaks. Malcolm goes int the hall bathroom. Pauline into their room. Running water groans through the old pipes.

dialogues.text: Where are you going? I thought we were having a conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're starting to annoy me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude walks -- he passes an open door: Malcolm is shavin his moustache -- the electric razor whirring.

dialogues.text: Claude enters.   It's empty. Her brown notebook rests on bedside table.   He hesitates then opens it: It's packed with writing -- a nearly indecipherable cursi in black ink. The name Claude can be made out on the page Claude takes the book and climbs up into bed. He nestles against the pillow and squints to read the writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Claude startles.   Margot stands in the doorway with a gl of water.

dialogues.text: I didn't think you came home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where would I be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't Josh and Dad come to the wedding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been through this.    Go to bed. Claude slides down to the floor.    He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I sleep in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can put a pillow between us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   Just for tonight. Claude takes a long pillow and places it like a barrier i the bed. We stay on him as he waits. Finally Margot climb into the covers in a nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you were a baby I wouldn't let anyone else hold you. I think that may have been a mistake.

dialogues.text: Malcolm, his moustache gone, a cigarette dangling from hi mouth, hammers in a stake at the base of a collapsed, whi tent. A workman holds a pole steadily. Pauline sets up chairs around a series of tables. Ingrid idles a few feet away. They're in the midst of talking:

dialogues.text: Why was it a secret?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I didn't want to get you excited before it was real. It's not really a baby yet. In two more weeks we can celebrate together, okay?

dialogues.text: Why did you tell Margot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she's my sister and I trust her. How do you feel about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want a sister. Pauline touches Ingrid's hair gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to go get Wizard. She runs toward the house.   Pauline marches toward Malco

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margot told Claude something I expressly told her in confidence. And he told Ingrid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAULINE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm stunned that she put me in this position. It's so fucking infuriating. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it's that thing where-- PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say anything. You know what...just be there for me. Silently. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do I have to be so careful around her, but everyone is allowed to make fun of me? MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if -- PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm, what did I just say? (sighs) You know, I just want you to take my side, I don't need you to make it better. Malcolm puts his hand awkwardly on her shoulder. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ingrid's really upset about it. Fuck. I can't believe she did this to me! (pause) I didn't tell you because... I didn't want you to feel like you had to marry me. I found out right before our seminar... I'm pregnant. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...does that sound good to you? MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still digesting Margot telling Claude. What a fucking nut job. (quickly) Sorry. I think I'm really happy.

dialogues.text: Ingrid is watching from across the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here, honey! Ingrid hurries through the sparkly, dewy grass.   Pauline her and they spin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margot!   Claude!

dialogues.text: Wizard!    Wiz! Margot enters the frame.   The kids walk ahead. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Ingrid brought him in last night, but we couldn't find him this morning. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh boy. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you tell Claude I'm pregnant? MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. PAULINE

dialogues.text: He wants to know. If I don't tell him, he figures it out. INGRID (O.S.)

dialogues.text: Where is Wizard? Ingrid approaches with Claude. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, honey. Ingrid sinks into her mother's body.   Claude and Margot ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't let him go out into the road or something where something could've happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would you think I'd do something like that? That's awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just...    I'm just making sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a terrible thing to say to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean on purpose, I just meant maybe in case...you knew something. I'm sorry.

dialogues.text: Margot enters and opens the refrigerator. She gets out a white wine bottle. She turns around and jumps, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woa! Malcolm sits at the table, eating saltines out of the box pad and paper in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, sorry. I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I...    I should've looked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just writing my vows. Trying to do something appropriate but also funny -- not jokey, more character based humor. Margot pours herself a glass of wine. She looks to Malcol to see if he wants some. He shakes his head. She takes a long drink. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You having an okay time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah.    Besides Wizard getting --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we'll...we'll find him...or else, I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We won't. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, or else he's dead or something. (pause) It means a lot to Paul that you came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Silence.   Malcolm mumbles a tune. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, this is the same toaster we had here as kids. Paul is so weird. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you've heard the news. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   Congratulations. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty cool. Hard to fully take in. It's a little abstract still. I haven't had that thing yet where you realize that you're not the most important person in the world. I'm anxious for that to happen. I guess I have to thank you -- I wouldn't know yet if you hadn't arrived. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I can't help but worry I'll pass some not so great genes onto the kid. I mean, in my family there's a lot of hand washing, you know. I don't have it, but my brother does. (pause) You working on anything now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides the thing with Dick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right. He nods.   She nods.    Silence. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about you? MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm working on some acrylic paint -- MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody fills the ice cube trays. Malcolm stops, immediately embarrassed. Margot is looking the freezer. She takes out the trays and brings them to t sink. She runs the water. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, what were you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.    It doesn't matter. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, what were you saying? MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It really... Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. She treads back to the refrigerator, balancing the full trays. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was saying I'm doing these abstractions in acrylic paint. But it's not... I'm not getting paid or anything. I don't know, I hate that question, "What do you do?" MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asked me. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm exhales in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pauline and Malcolm open the gate to the Vogler's propert

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we shouldn't mention the tree, we should let them know that there will be people and music on Saturday and it will be louder than usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that they can come for a glass of champagne. But you tell them. I think they respond to you better. They approach the Vogler's sun-worn and paint chipped hou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I am ultimately one of them. You shouldn't've made me shave the stache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hey, Ingrid is asking me if I was ever gay. Do you know what that's about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Mr. Vogler, wearing a fleece vest and carrying a hatchet his shoulders, tramples out of the brush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Vogler stops.   His face is jagged and worn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Pauline. This is Malcolm. We've met before. We're your neighbors. The man watches them strangely with icy blue eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VOGLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna cut that tree down? PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we grew up with that tree and we're getting married under it Saturday and -- She waits for Malcolm to jump in.    He doesn't.   Vogler softly, but sternly: VOGLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roots are growing into our property. It's rotting, it's killing our plants. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had a tree doctor out and he said it was healthy. Pauline smacks Malcolm's arm. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it hurt you to say anything? MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?   What do you want from me? PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're making me do the whole fucking thing. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You brought up the tree. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He brought up -- She stops herself.   She says to Vogler: PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... This was better thought-through back at the house. Pauline's gaze goes above Vogler's head -- like Margot described earlier. He runs his hand through his hair as i something might be caught in there. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were wondering if you and your wife -- I'm sorry I forgot her name -- would like to come over for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VOGLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should ask her. She makes the plans. I'm going to go in now. He tramps inside.   The screen door bangs. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I felt like you didn't give me a chance to say what I wanted to say. Pauline hits him in the chest and starts to walk away. Malcolm comes after her, his rage growing. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to punch that guy in the nose! PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never hit anyone. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have too! PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of -- You don't know them. They're not around because I've punched them. A smile breaks across Pauline's face.   Malcolm seethes. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't laugh, Pauline. It's not funny. I'll fucking punch your sister. Malcolm clenches his fists.    He points at Vogler's plac MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The threat is not out there. It's in our house. It's sleeping in my studio. I mean, I wouldn't actually hit her, but I feel...I feel like doing it. She's such a fucking idiot. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not an idiot.    You might not like her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is. She is an idiot!    You're an idiot. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're both fucking morons. I'm so fucking... I'm trying so hard. You don't give me any credit. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is wrong? MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I have the emotional version of whatever bad feng shui would be. I don't know. You tell me, you understand this shit. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you drink your teas? MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I drank my fucking teas! Don't judge me now. Really, I think when you look back at this you're going to see I'm not acting like a crazy person. That this is the right reaction. In proportion with what is going on. This is right! Malcolm looks around furiously. The only thing available him is a leafy stalk. He pulls on it, but it won't uproot He tears the leaves off in a rage. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the most oddly self- conscious form of rage I've ever -- MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate you. Exhausted he approaches her.   He says, still with anger: MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's make love.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Pauline walks back to the house, buttoning her dress. She looks up suddenly and stops: A man watches her from the l He holds a bouquet of flowers. Pauline runs to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim... They embrace.    Her hand cups the back of his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad! Claude runs from the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pauline, Malcolm, Margot, Jim, Claude and Ingrid eat fish stew and peasant bread. Jim's flowers sit in a vase. He wears a tan knit bracelet that Ingrid made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a difficult    decision because Claude has so many    friends at school now, but it    is expensive and Bronx Science is a    great public school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't get into Stuyvesant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not a good test taker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to Stuy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (caught off-guard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather stay at Packer, but it's so expensive. Malcolm lifts up a bottle of Jameson from the floor near chair and pours himself another stiff drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josh is a great test taker, but Claude thinks more abstractly. He's more creative. Right? CLAUDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so. Jim smiles warmly at his son. JIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw the one armed man who really has two arms at the bodega. CLAUDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you give him confusing change? JIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. I tripped him up with some nickels. And a Canadian quarter. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I tried the other day? Sitting down to pee. Have you done this, Jim? JIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...no. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did it as a lark. As a joke really. I was going to call Pauline in and say, guess what I'm doing here... PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I didn't get to have that experience. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking, you know, my dad used to say, "Why stand when you can sit." And this is a really good example of that. I mean, it took me so long to try because I was embarrassed. (to the sisters) You guys do it all the time. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never sit down in a public place. I squat and hover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ingrid goes wide eyed for a moment. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I recommend it.     At least to try it. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, I'm sorry about the room. It's usually Malcolm's storage room so it's kind of make-shift right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine. Margot stares at Jim. JIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margot, open your gift. An unopened present in blue tissue paper sits beside Marg plate. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get self-conscious opening presents in front of people.    This weekend is about Pauline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...poo.     Open it Margot. Margot slowly unties the white ribbon and peels away the tape. Pauline groans: PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, get to it. Margot takes out a pair of furry slippers. MALCOLM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those look warm. JIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember last year in Vermont you said your feet were freezing. Her eyes find Claude who watches his parents carefully. S leans across the table to Jim and they kiss chastely and briskly on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim drives with Margot in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already have slippers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's okay.   Two sets are fine, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes me sad to get a present that I already have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes me feel like you don't know me. She jams her pinky into her ear trying to get at the bug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with your ear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked you not to come. I was so clear and you did it anyway so blithely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need time alone to sort this out. You can't just run away --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, so we're here.   I'm giving you this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying a joke)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now you're putting too much pressure on me. Jim smiles crookedly at her. She half-smiles back.   He t a moment, preparing to speak. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that? His headlights catch a woman cowering at the roadside. Th pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep driving. Jim slowly pulls over to the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...no...no. Jim, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me just... Jim gets out of the car.     A sobbing woman crouches, cr a bloody dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please help me. Jim comes toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please help me. He got hit by a car. Please help me. Margot opens her door and steps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim... Jim kneels down by the whining pit bull.    The woman scr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful, he might bite you! Jim suddenly lifts up the twitching animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim drives, his front covered in blood. Margot is shot-gu The lady rides in back with the panting pit in her lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry...he's dying.     He's dying. Margot puts her hands over her ears.    Jim speeds up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't do anything. Roger is an innocent. He's an innocent creature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stand her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim comes outside tucking his wallet in his back pocket. Margot sits on the car hood smoking a joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You paid, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't have her purse with her. It wasn't so expensive. Roger's going to live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't give a fuck about Roger. And...that makes me feel like shit. You make me feel like shit. I wouldn't have stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you would've.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I wouldn't've. I would have kept driving. I hate myself when I'm with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frustrated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margot, I'm not... I can't talk to you when you're this fucked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just like Claude in that way...you make me feel guilty. Sometimes I find you so despicable. Margot stubs out the joint on the car roof. Jim suddenly removes his sweater and puts it around her shoulders. He fishes into his pants pocket for his keys. Tears start do Margot's cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before you gave me your sweater I think I didn't realize I was cold. Margot leans in to him, her forehead presses against his cheek. After a moment, he puts his arms around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take me home and go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margot smokes by the open door. She drinks a glass of whi wine. Pauline eats from a left-over Chinese container.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it were someone else I'd understand it, I'd feel sympathy even. But since it's me, I just feel bad. And horribly critical. I haven't been able to tell Claude what's happening. And I have to. I'm going to. (frustrated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I be all these people? How can I be married to Jim. And fuck Dick. And want them both and then neither of them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. We're at the age where we're becoming invisible to men and if a guy wants to fuck us, it's very tempting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm saying, if you get your sense of self from being fuckable and that starts to wane -- it's very hard. I almost had an affair too. But you know, you don't have to do it. You can, I don't know, get a manicure or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margot grows furious.   She turns to hide her face. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I tell people you're my closest friend. I really miss you. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely) Me too. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can't help feeling that you really came to my wedding because I live a mile away from the guy you're fucking. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Pauline. You make it sound like I'm using you. PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. There is a long silence between them. Finally, Pauline indicates to Margot that she has something in her nostril PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a... Margot clears her nose quickly with her finger. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I get it? PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think so. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Paul, what are you doing getting married to this guy? He's not good enough for you. He's so coarse, he's like guys we rejected when we were sixteen. You know...don't make a mistake like this. (pause) I'm sorry, maybe I have no right to say that, but you know I'm truthful so... Would you rather I lie? PAULINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who should I be with then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smashing sound. Margot steps outside: Two hooded figure turn over a recycling can, glass smashes on the ground. Garbage is strewn across the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey, you! You pick that up. I will call the police. This is our property. Pick that up. Pauline remains seated at the table, stunned.    Margot c back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malcolm crams the trash back in the cans. He sees somethi amidst the milk cartons and corn husks. He reaches down a lifts up a severed pig's hoof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude and Ingrid idle in the tall grass calling to Wizar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dogs usually come back, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to your dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He went to Vermont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't want to come to the wedding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think he could...    I think he couldn't. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to see me dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Claude dances. The gangly weeds blow around him. There's rustling in the brush. A patch of fur catches Ingrid's ey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under her breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wizard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The animal is gone. A figure appears in the distance behind Claude. The boy, Vogler's son, approaches shirtless in swimming trunks. Ingrid's attention goes to him. CLAUDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not watching. The boy comes into focus. He holds a dead squirrel by its tail. Ingrid backs up next to Claude. The boy stops a few feet away and hurls the squirrel at them. The kids jump b as it lands at their feet. BOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going? CLAUDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping) We have to get home. BOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that your girlfriend? CLAUDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she's my cousin. BOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a fruity? CLAUDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um...no. BOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ingrid) You a fruity? INGRID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with certainty) No. BOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will hurt you. Claude takes Ingrid's arm and they start to walk away. INGRID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a Vogler. CLAUDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's just a stupid boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude sneaks a look over his shoulder -- the boy follows Claude's gait quickens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it, I have a rock in my sandal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Ingrid. Ingrid slows, lifts her leg and removes a sandal. The boy behind them. Claude yanks Ingrid's arm and she topples ov

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oww! Claude leans down to help her. The boy leaps on Claude. They both crash to the ground and roll through the grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him off me. Ingrid! Ingrid hesitates then runs toward the house. Claude wrestles with the boy. The boy growls. He grabs ho of Claude's arms and sinks his teeth into Claude's should

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ayy!     Help me! Claude kicks and yanks himself free.     He runs wildly. Close on Claude.    Tears stream down.   He coughs and sp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude bursts through the front door. Ingrid sees Claude runs to the kitchen. Margot, in a suit, goes over notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woa, don't run so fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a boy! He bit me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who bit you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boy.    A Vogler!   Where's Ingrid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see. He tilts his head, she leans down and looks at his neck. There are red and purple bite marks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm calling the police. Claude grabs her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, don't! It'll get worse. Why did you say anything to them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude, this isn't my fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That boy bit me because you couldn't keep your fat mouth shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude, you're being a jerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shit in your shoes and then you fuck them! Margot smacks Claude in the face.   Ingrid stares wide ey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A placard reads: A Conversation with Margot Zeller and Di Koosman. People mull about with drinks. Pauline and Claud admire the display of Margot's books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really want to know? I'll tell you. She wrote a story about Lenny and me. (flips through pages)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's in here. I mean we were talking almost every day at this point and there was no warning. Maybe a couple of remarks that she'd used some things of ours... Then The New Yorker comes -- we have a subscription -- and there's the story and... It's things we said and did -- stuff I told her in confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it helped end our marriage. I read it and thought, "She hates me."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't hate you. Pauline stares at a blown up author photo of her sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think? Margot tried to murder me when we were girls. She put me on a baking sheet, sprinkled me with paprika and put me in the oven.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The crowd files in.   Margot and Dick stand in a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim was here. Dick flips through some notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Jim still writing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told him to go to Vermont without me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to see him tell a linear story for a change. Jim never wanted to make it easy for the reader, did he. The nicest man I've ever met, but he can't play the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not joining him. I'm going to stay here and then...we'll see. Right. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't ask you to do that. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy's pointing at us...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Margot and Dick sit on stools holding microphones in fron rows of fold-out chairs. Only a few empty seats remain. Pauline and Claude sit in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very interested in your story "Middle Children." Some people applaud, but it trickles off before it gets started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The father is a loathsome character yet we also feel a strange sympathy for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well I was very interested in exploring a father-daughter relationship. While he clings desperately to her, suffocates her really, he also silently resents the responsibility of parenthood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's this sexualized push-pull with Daphne which I find --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He craves isolation really. I always thought of him as someone who so over identifies with everyone around him that he begins to lose all sense of himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make his only recourse to abandon his family, including his beloved daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, that's true.   That's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I write historical fiction so I don't have to answer to this, but I wonder for someone who writes so nakedly about family, how autobiographical is this portrait? Margot rests her lips on the tip of the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father was a loving person. He had his days, of course, but...he was devoted to us as children. I wouldn't have written this portrait were it true. Pauline nods slightly. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm interested in how the father could be in fact a portrait of you. Margot stares, dumbstruck. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Umm...I don't... Why do you assume it's based on... We all take from life. I had to have our refrigerator repaired the other day at our apartment in Manhattan. I was alone with a guy, I think he was Puerto Rican, sent over by...Whirlpool, I think it is who made our fridge. Although he said he worked for an independent organization who Whirlpool subcontracts. I think he was retarded. There was an anger in him and suddenly I became afraid for my life. I called Jim at NYU. I asked him to come home. Margot stops.   Her face is awash in sweat. Pauline takes Claude's hand and presses it to her chest. eyes widen, fixed on his mother. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might be Frigidaire... I'm sorry... I don't... I'm not sure what I'm... I think I need to take a moment... She stands and walks off the stage. She realizes she stil has the mike. She goes back and places it on her seat. MARGOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost incoherently) You're an asshole...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margot grabs a pill from her pocket, puts it on her tongu and drinks from the faucet. There is a knocking. Margot opens the door. Claude looks up at her. Pauline and Dick wait in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to be alone right now, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'll tell you sometime. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Go with mom.    I'll see you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said, mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you know what I mean. Go with Pauline. Jesus, do I...do I need to spell it out for you? (she points)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go. With. Her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A simple, spare space, empty except for Pauline and Claud

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're your mom's favorite.     Do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think she has a favorite.

dialogues.text: PAULINE
